pullRequest.title: Feature/virtual scroller
pullRequest.bodyText:
Intent
Improve performance of the Console pane when a large amount of data has accumulated in that window.
Fixes #6042
Approach
Only show a moving window of message elements much like Slack and other similar programs. When scrolling up/down a set of elements (stored in "buckets") is added to the view while another bucket on the opposite end is hidden.
QA Notes
There is a lot of subtle DOM manipulation added to the console functionality here. It's fairly self-contained but it is very possible that there are cases where GWT code is trying to directly manipulate the DOM that I missed.
I think just putting as much varied content as possible into the console is the best place to start for testing. I'll be available to work closely with ya'll for testing here because it is such a quirky feature.

nodes.bodyText: Have you tested this in a production build? GWT obfuscates class names, so you will either need to pass the class name into the setup method at runtime or tell GWT to use a non-obfuscated name.
Should this be disabled by default?

These parameters are probably somewhat machine dependent (i.e. with more hardware you can have more buckets w/o noticeable performance degradation), so it'd be nice if they could be set via an advanced (no UI) option; your call.
This would need to be removed to make the virtual scroller usable in other panes. Maybe it should be supplied as a callback?
Nit: VirtualConsole. prefix is unnecessary (here and elsewhere)
Maybe I'm misreading this, but wouldn't we need one instance of VirtualScrollerNative per VirtualConsole?

commit.message: PR feedback for virtual scroller. refactor to use the VirtualScrollerManager
add overrides for FakePrefs to tests compile

nodes.bodyText: You can replace this if/else with a single call to restartRequirement.setRestartRequired() (added fairly recently).
nit, we usually put else on a separate line
As discussed elsewhere, be great to have some unit-tests for the virtual scrolling mechanism here and/or in the ConsoleOutputWriteTests.

There's also interaction with our server-side (I think) console-output limiting logic to consider. For example, try this sequence:
> for (i in 1:2000) cat(c(i, "\n"))
1000
1001
...
2000
Notice that you only see the output from 1000 - 2000 (but still see the original prompt with no indication stuff is missing in between; prior to this change the prompt would have been lost, too).
> for (i in 2001:4000) cat(c(i, "\n"))
3000
3001
...
4000
Now you can scroll back and indeed are seeing > 1000 lines, but these gaps are unexpected, I think.
Should we clear the loading_ flag here? (doesn't look like it effects correctness but would be consistent?)
